sec_filings.special_note: 84-day delay approved by DOJ under national security exception

key_facts.attack_vector: Unauthorized access to third-party cloud platform (Snowflake)
key_facts.vulnerability: Compromised Snowflake workspace, no MFA on customer accounts
key_facts.individuals_affected: Nearly all AT&T wireless customers - 109-110 million
key_facts.data_compromised: Call and text metadata (May 1-Oct 31 2022, plus Jan 2 2023)
key_facts.metadata_includes: Phone numbers, call durations, cell site identification
key_facts.notable: First known use of Item 1.05(c) national security delay provision

expected_answer_elements: Call and text metadata, not content
Filed under new Item 1.05 with delay justification
Part of broader Snowflake campaign affecting 165+ companies
Demonstrates new SEC disclosure rules in action
Q11_AT&T_Snowflake.sec_rule_notes: Demonstrates Item 1.05(c) exception for national security delays

sec_filings.special_note: Used Item 8.01 instead of 1.05 - no materiality determination yet

key_facts.attack_vector: Unauthorized access to third-party cloud database (Snowflake)
key_facts.data_compromised: Names, addresses, emails, phone numbers, partial credit cards, order details
key_facts.third_party: Snowflake breach - part of 165+ customer campaign
key_facts.disclosure_choice: Filed under Item 8.01 NOT Item 1.05 - no material impact determined

expected_answer_elements: No materiality determination at time of filing
Demonstrates company choosing Item 8.01 for immaterial/undetermined incidents
Example of SEC guidance in practice: use 8.01 when materiality unclear
Q12_Live_Nation_Ticketmaster.sec_rule_notes: Example of Item 8.01 vs 1.05 distinction per May 2024 SEC guidance

key_facts.attack_vector: Unauthorized access to third-party cloud database (Snowflake)
key_facts.data_compromised: SSNs, driver's licenses, government IDs, names, email addresses

expected_answer_elements: Disclosed $3M expense but didn't deem material
Part of Snowflake mass breach campaign
Shows company can disclose costs without materiality determination
Example of voluntary disclosure under Item 8.01
Q13_Advance_Auto_Parts.sec_rule_notes: Shows Item 8.01 can include financial impacts without triggering Item 1.05

sec_filings.key_item: Item 8.01 Other Events - Financial Impact Update

key_facts.attack_vector: Ransomware attack on third-party vendor CDK Global
key_facts.operational_impact: Dealer management system offline, affecting sales, service, inventory
key_facts.financial_impact: $1.50 per share EPS hit for Q2 2024
key_facts.affected_operations: 15,000 dealerships nationally, AutoNation one of many
key_facts.disclosure_choice: Item 8.01 for supply chain vendor incident

expected_answer_elements: Two 8-Ks: initial disclosure + financial impact update
Operations disrupted but continued with manual processes
Example of downstream victim disclosing upstream vendor attack
Q14_AutoNation_CDK.sec_rule_notes: Demonstrates disclosure of third-party vendor incidents under Item 8.01

key_facts.attack_vector: Credential stuffing - reused passwords from other breaches
key_facts.data_compromised: Login credentials, limited payment info (last 4 digits)
key_facts.remediation: Forced password resets, enabled 2FA for all 80M accounts

expected_answer_elements: Two separate credential stuffing attacks (March and April 2024)
Demonstrates credential stuffing as distinct from infrastructure breach
Shows progressive disclosure of expanding incident
Q15_Roku_Credential_Stuffing.sec_rule_notes: Example of credential stuffing vs. system breach disclosure

sec_filings.special_note: Updated to 6.9 million affected via DNA Relatives feature

key_facts.vulnerability: DNA Relatives opt-in feature amplified exposure
key_facts.individuals_affected: 6.9 million (5.5M via DNA Relatives, 1.4M family trees)
key_facts.data_compromised: Genetic ancestry, DNA matches, family trees, profile info
key_facts.amplification: DNA Relatives feature exposed 6.9M users' data
key_facts.targeted: Specifically targeted Jewish and Chinese ancestry users

expected_answer_elements: 14,000 direct breaches amplified to 6.9M via DNA Relatives feature
Credential stuffing with targeted ethnic groups
Demonstrates secondary exposure via platform features
Shows how opt-in features can amplify breach impact
Q16_23andMe_DNA_Relatives.sec_rule_notes: Filed before new Item 1.05 effective date (Dec 18, 2023)

key_facts.data_compromised: Names, SSNs, financial accounts, credit/debit cards with PINs
key_facts.double_extortion: Re-encrypted during recovery, second attack Nov 27
key_facts.ransom_negotiation: Stalled negotiations led to second attack
key_facts.financial_impact: Offering 10-15% discounts to win back customers

expected_answer_elements: Double ransomware attack - re-encrypted during recovery
Shows evolution from initial to final impact assessment
Q17_Henry_Schein_Double_Attack.sec_rule_notes: Filed before Dec 18, 2023 Item 1.05 effective date - would be Item 1.05 today

key_facts.financial_impact: $57 million costs by Q3 2024 ($49M initial, $8M Q3)
key_facts.market_share: Lost market share, 90% recovered by May 2024

expected_answer_elements: Filed before Item 1.05 (would likely be 1.05 today)
Demonstrates material operational and financial impact
Multi-quarter disclosure in 10-Qs of ongoing costs
Q18_Clorox_Manufacturing_Disruption.sec_rule_notes: Filed before Dec 18, 2023 - significant enough to likely be Item 1.05 under new rules

sec_filings.form_type: Data breach notifications to state AGs
sec_filings.special_note: Santander Bank Spain public filing may exist

key_facts.individuals_affected: 12,786 US employees, plus customers in Spain/Chile/Uruguay
key_facts.data_compromised: Names, SSNs, bank accounts (employee payroll data)

expected_answer_elements: Part of massive Snowflake campaign (165+ orgs)
Employee payroll data including SSNs and bank accounts
Santander Holdings USA is private (parent is public Spanish bank)
Demonstrates international scope of supply chain attack
Q19_Santander_Bank_Snowflake.sec_rule_notes: US subsidiary is private, but incident notable for Snowflake campaign scope

Q20_National_Public_Data.company_name: National Public Data / Jerico Pictures, Inc.

sec_filings.special_note: Largest US breach ever - 2.9 billion records

key_facts.data_compromised: SSNs, full names, addresses, DOB, phone numbers, emails
key_facts.data_scope: Background check data broker, decades of records
key_facts.notable: Largest US data breach in history by volume

expected_answer_elements: Largest US breach ever - 2.9 billion records
Background check company with decades of accumulated data
SSNs, addresses, DOB for most US citizens
Would absolutely be Item 1.05 if public company
Q20_National_Public_Data.sec_rule_notes: Private company - included to show what would be massive Item 1.05 disclosure
